content.title: Negative Pressure Wound Therapy
content.summary: Negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT) applies controlled subatmospheric pressure to wounds, promoting granulation tissue formation, reducing edema, and facilitating wound healing. It is widely used in vascular surgery for complex wounds and exposed grafts.
content.definition: A therapeutic system that applies subatmospheric (negative) pressure to a wound through a sealed dressing, promoting tissue perfusion, granulation, and wound contraction

mechanism_of_action.microdeformation: Cell stretch at foam-tissue interface stimulates proliferation
mechanism_of_action.fluid_removal: Evacuation of interstitial fluid, reduced edema
mechanism_of_action.increased_perfusion: Enhanced blood flow to wound edges

foam.black_foam: More aggressive granulation, may cause wound ingrowth

components.drape: Occlusive adhesive film to seal wound

pressure.reduced: -75 to -100 mmHg for painful wounds or near vessels
pressure.rationale: Higher pressure = more granulation but more pain

mode.continuous: Constant pressure; standard for most applications
mode.intermittent: Cycles on/off; may enhance granulation but less tolerated

instillation.description: NPWT with periodic instillation of fluid

absolute: Necrotic tissue with eschar (requires debridement first)

vessel_protection.requirement: Protect exposed vessels with non-adherent layer or tissue
vessel_protection.risk: Vessel erosion if foam contacts vessel directly

foam_placement: Cut foam to fit wound (not pack tightly)
Fill dead space without excessive compression
drape_application: Cover foam and 3-5cm of surrounding skin
Create small hole for tubing connection

dressing_changes.frequency: Every 48-72 hours (may vary by wound and system)
dressing_changes.assessment: Granulation progress, drainage, signs of infection

exposed_graft.approach: NPWT as bridge to tissue coverage
exposed_graft.protection: Non-adherent layer over graft before foam
exposed_graft.goal: Granulation tissue coverage allowing skin graft or flap

groin_wounds.challenge: Contoured anatomy, proximity to femoral vessels

outcomes.granulation: Typically 50-100% increase in granulation tissue formation
outcomes.healing_time: Variable; may reduce time to wound closure
outcomes.graft_take: Improved skin graft incorporation when used as bolster

complications.vessel_erosion: Rare but potentially catastrophic if foam contacts vessel

content.statement: Negative Pressure Wound Therapy is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Wound-Care that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Negative Pressure Wound Therapy helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Negative Pressure Wound Therapy.

definition.@value: Therapeutic system applying subatmospheric pressure to wounds to promote healing

medicalCode.description: Negative pressure wound therapy (total wound(s) surface area less than or equal to 50 sq cm)

learning_objectives: Explain mechanisms of action of NPWT
List indications and contraindications in vascular surgery
Apply NPWT to exposed graft scenarios
clinical_pearls: Standard pressure: -125 mmHg; reduce for pain or near vessels
NEVER place foam directly on exposed blood vessels
White foam (PVA) is less aggressive than black foam (PU)
NPWT with instillation (NPWTi) for infected wounds
Dressing changes every 48-72 hours; assess granulation progress
